text: The President The weird beauty that water and limestone have created over thousands of years in the underground caverns and galleries of the Waitomo caves has made them famous. But there's another feature more unusual still in these caves. The main cavern, the cathedral, draped and fluted by the centuries, gives a rare rich dimension to sound that has tempted many famous singers to try it. And now a Maori group has assembled underground to sing a well-loved song with the sparkle that only Waitomo can give it. Pekyne, Pachimai'i, ma'iara, comea'a'o, Our own, you know, my road, the United States and aughty aughty a man, We're Come at a-ho Cher-O-Hale Cher-Raw-Hare. K'ra-Kare-Koe-Kare-re-law and a-do-o-o-way, l'-l-l-do-on-day. Hey, nice'ma, ala, ha'i, Gaeli, Gaeli, da'i-da-do. New Zealand toy manufacturers are heading for Christmas. Doll's heads are now made of unbreakable vinyl plastic which has a life-like quality. But it's the eyes that win the heart of a little girl, eyes that sleep beside a child after the pleasures of the day. Almost a quarter of New Zealanders are under nine years old. 500,000 vivid imaginations. To little girls, this is Judy energetic youngster, there's Dobbin. Eternal toys that take a child a million miles away, yet still keep him under the watchful eye of Mum. I'm gonnae.
